title.narrative: MGSA - Strengthening acess to rights and social security programmes to the poor and marginalised

description.narrative: The project focuses on facilitating non-discriminatory access to rights, entitlements, social and financial protection measures of the state by the already vulnerable and marginalised owing to a variety of factors which the Covid 19 pandemic and its resultant effect has only accentuated and deepened. More specifically the proposed project would primarily focus following aspects; - Create constant awareness and messaging around health, hygiene, sanitation and preventive behaviours along with entitlement and relief access - Strengthen the agency of the vulnerable and marginalized people and facilitate linkages to various social and financial security schemes and measures, rights, entitlements and relief measures - Facilitation for access to job through the National Rural Employment Guarantee Act which ensures 100 days of work

The project would result in making the proposed marginalised communities more resilient with enhanced information to deal with Covid 19 and improved access to social and financial protection entitlements and benefits from the state. The process of implementation of the project is envisaged to vitally engage the local governance mechanism and functionaries who are responsible for delivery of these entitlements and benefits. These engagements are likely to have a longer-term effect and move towards the construct of better resilience and space for the excluded communities targeted by the project. While the proposed work will be carried out with all the targeted population, owing to the short duration of the project specific results will be limited during the project period and would continue to gain benefits beyond the project period.

description.narrative: 1.Community quarantine centres are prepared to deal with the existing population and potential influx of people both in border gates 2. Reduction in risk for populations and minimise the stigma around COVID-19 which allows people to self declare the symptomatic cases 3. Improved behaviour of people towards COVID-19 positive cases and enhanced solidarity 4. Women and men with disabilities are engaged, better protected and included in the response activities and provided support 5. Access to correct and trust worthy Covid1i information through verified and reliable platforms to enable people make informed decisions 6. Vulnerable households including people with disabilities have access to Cash to support their basic needs to deal with restrictions/lockdowns and suspension of businesses

PPE FOR QUARANTINE VOLUNTEERS: This project provide focused support in preparation against the spread of COVID-19 in rural and peri-urban border areas. This will involve PPE at community quarantine facilities and information management support based on the feedback received from the government/facility managers at Myawaddy and district medical officers in Kwakeriek, village administration and at risk communities across all the townships including Thandaunggyi and Baw Ga Lae (a sub-township of Hpaan). - CASH ASSISTANCE: The assistance would also include multi purpose cash transfers to meet the multiple needs around health, hygiene and food both with the returnees/families and other vulnerable groups. Markets in the area are still functional and communities could procure basic food items and medicines. - KEY HEALTH MESSAGING: Further the initiative would be complimented by provision of information on COVID prevention and facilities in the identified townships. There is a need for funds for Covid-19 related awareness messaging which local organisations are not able to spread effectively. While community quarantine centres have been set up, they lack resources and effective monitoring of those in quarantine.

title.narrative: Preparedness and response to primary and secondary impacts of COVID-19 on IDPs in Benue State

description.narrative: Benue state is currently challenged with a complex emergency which includes violent conflict, social inequalities and underlying poverty exacerbated by natural hazards including flood and diseases such as HIV/AIDS, malaria and other health conditions such as malnutrition. The state has just recovered from a flood emergency which hit many LGAs between August and October 2019 and currently combating the heightened insecurity as a result of the violent conflicts involving herders and farmers. The underlying factors have contributed to the widespread displacement witnessed across the state leaving over 400,000 IDPs across the state largely in Agatu, Guma, Makurdi, Oju LGAs, and over 7,000 refugees in Kwande LGA from Cameroon. The State currently has 430 confirmed cases of COVID-19 with 139 recovered and 9 fatalities. This is also added to the recurring health challenges from lasar fever and a water-borne disease which has been ravaging communities in the state since December 2019. With state government being overwhelmed, the very agrarian communities of Benue state who contribute largely to the food production in Nigeria require support to overcome the impacts of the COVID-19.

title.narrative: EHF WASH Response to Cholera Affected Communities in South Omo, Ethiopia

description.narrative: The prevalence/impacts of water-borne diseases/cholera is reduced in the Bena Tsemay, Male, Selamago and Semen Ari woredas and surrounding areas; Access of the population to drinking water in the four woredas and surrounding areas is improved; Sanitation services are improved; The proportion of the population sensitized and who have positively changed their behaviour towards hygiene and health has increased;

This project plans to increase the coverage of clean water, hand washing facilities, sanitation and hygiene services to reduce potential risks of fatalities and contain the spread of cholera outbreak in four woredas of South Omo Zone. Major activities include: • Rehabilitation 28 non-functional water schemes and 2 pipe line extensions from existing water schemes with construction of additional water points, • Construction of 12 semi-permanent latrines, construction of 26 wash basins and provision of handwashing facilities at health centres, schools, CTCs and other public places, • Enhancing awareness of communities to control and prevent the cholera outbreak and COVID-19, • Provision of WASH NFIs (soaps) and water purification tabs, • Setting up and support community rehydration centres, • Provision of COVID-19 prevention materials for distribution team (staffs and volunteers) - masks, glove and hand sanitizer, • Post distribution monitoring.

title.narrative: Preparedness and Resilience to address impacts of COVID-19, support IDP communities in Badghis

description.narrative:
Outcome 1: Spread of the COVID-19 pandemic is contained, and GBV cases are decreased. Activities: - - Conduct rapid assessment to identify and prioritize vulnerable households. - Conduct community level awareness raising on COVID-19 prevention - Print and distribute nationally approved Risk Communication IEC materials - Conduct digital awareness through radio, TV, banner, poster on COVID-19, stress management, GBV/SGBV. - Conduct sessions on hygiene promotion - Distribution of hygiene kits - Identify and refer vulnerable women who suffer from Mental Health stresses. to mental Health services
Outcome 2: Increased access to food security and livelihood opportunities Activities: - Distribution of standard food packages. - Distribution of special nutrition packages - - Gardening training for 50 people including 25 farmers and 25 women head of households in Badghis - Distribution of fertilizer, vegetable seeds, improved wheat seeds and farm toolkits for 50 farmers in Badghis

The COVID-19 Response in Kabul Informal Settlements (KIS) and Place of Origin in Badghis, will be implemented in two IDPs camps/ Informal Settlements in Kabul and 12 villages of Qala-e-Naw and Ab-Kamari districts of Badghis province over a 6 months period (September 1, 2020 to Feb 28, 2021). The intervention will be a multi-sector response covering awareness raising, WASH, food security and livelihood support to mitigate COVID-19 impact on IDPs and vulnerable hard-to-reach communities in Kabul and remote parts of Badghis province. Using integrated, adaptive rapidly scalable approaches leveraging on national and community partner networks, faith/ traditional leaders, youth (prioritizing women and girls), displaced, socially excluded, elderly, people with disabilities and underlying health conditions. title.narrative: Start Fund COVID-19 Project- PEAB

description.narrative: Burundi is classified as one of the least prepared countries according the Global Health Security Index (GHS Index) and with forty-two (42) confirmed COVID-19 cases. The Government of Burundi (GoB) has taken some measures such us putting incoming passengers from COVID-19 affected countries into quarantine and closing all borders including the international airport of Bujumbura. Observers from civil society and NGOs believe there are likely many more unreported cases of COVID-19 in the country due to the weakness of the surveillance system at the PoEs and the inefficient quarantine system due to lack of training and preparation of service providers involved as well as limited capacity quarantine spaces. With most of urban and middle class population gradually observing measures issued by the local health authorities in response to the pandemic, vulnerable groups, who are not well equipped to embrace these preventive measures like others due to the lack of information and basic WASH infrastructures, could constitute the hotbed of COVID-19 contamination and spread.

The proposed project will focuses deeply on three of the four objectives raised in the alert: 1. Community-based response through local partnership 2. Advocacy for community-led initiatives 3. Public Health Awareness around COVID-19 The project will strengthen the capacity of 1,100 religious leaders on education and awareness creation from 550 religious congregation in four provinces. Burundi is still having business as usal and the religious leaders, once trained are able to reach their congregation very well. Through this approach, we expect that the 1,100 trained religious leaders will reach additional 35,000 individuals through cascade model. In addition to the religious congregations, the project will work through 60 disaster committees in four provinces most at risk because of the movements of people between the borders, Makamba, Bujumbura, Rutana and Rumonge and 13 interfaith platforms in Bujumbura to reach at least 10,000 people with key preventive messages.

title.narrative: Integrated WASH Response to the Rohingya and Host population in Cox's Bazar

description.narrative: Awareness building:A total of 6 community mobilizers (who plan and execute distributions and oversee the awareness raising sessions) and 18 community volunteers will be trained on Covid-19 preventative measures and supported to raise awareness and assist in disinfection activities within the target communities.Over the three-months, these volunteers and mobilisers will conduct individual awareness-raising sessions, reaching around 25,000 individuals (including elderly and PWD) through bi-weekly dissemination plan.We will display 5000 IEC posters in the communal areas of both camps, and leaflets will be distributed.Distribution of Kits:We will distribute Hygiene Promotion Kits of WASH supplies (soap, mask, mug etc) to 550 vulnerable HH in the camps as per COVID-19 WASH sector distribution guidelines for high-risk members.We will also identify and distribute hygiene and dignity kits (hygiene-related materials for women and girls of reproductive age) to 200 HH based on vulnerability and number of females.Installation of solar lights:We will map the most vulnerable areas in the camps and install/distribute 100 Solar light for Bathing Cubicles and latrines.This will promote safer access to these facilities. Disinfection

The project will focus on improved WaSH services and awareness of Covid-19 prevention measures for a total of 5000 HH Rohingya refugees and influx-affected host communities. Hygiene promotion and Dignity kits will be distributed to 750 vulnerable households. We will install solar lights in 100 community bathing/toilet cubicles to promote protection and safe access to WASH facilities particularly for women, children, PWD and vulnerable adults. The project will also strengthen our existing awareness raising sessions and engagement through community mobilizers by providing in-depth orientations, reaching around 25,000 camp residents. The project would specifically target camp 14 (C block) and Camp 15 (B, C, & H blocks).

title.narrative: Response to COVID-19 pandemic on El Salvador´s women

description.narrative: The proposed project is focused on 3 strategies: 1) Knowledge generation to inform advocacy actions, 2) Legal and psychological support for victims of GBV at national level, and 3) Advocacy and accompaniment from women leaders to local victims of violence at the community level. This response is relevant at the current state of the crisis because authorities have disregarded the cases of violence against women, even when civil society organizations have announced increased aggressions during quarantine; furthermore, staff have difficulties to mobilize to the territory often, therefore, partner´s new strategy is to rely on local women that are properly trained and empowered to support victims at that level with legal and emotional tools. The first strategy includes the creation of a dedicated section on the impact of COVID-19 on ORMUSA´s Online Observatory of Violence Against Women, these statistics of GBV and femicides will inform advocacy actions from feminist organizations before authorities, mass media and international organizations. The second strategy will work to strengthen the response capacity of partner´s Legal Attention Centre with the addition of a lawyer and a psychologist to effectively respond to increased demand

services will be promoted using a social media campaign which will also refer to sexual and reproductive health´s rights. The third strategy seeks to advocate for women´s rights before local authorities with local leaders already trained in legislation and attention routes, who will become women´ rights promoters in 3 municipalities, they will also conduct small group trainings to empower women with information sharing and provide one to one support in cases of GBV. To complete this job, promoters will receive a kit with hygiene equipment to prevent transmission of COVID-19 and printed material including Salvadorian legislation in favour of women, service institutions, psychosocial activities, etc. In every activity, staff, promoters and beneficiaries will practice measures against COVID-19 according to partner and Christian Aid Guidelines for Field Visits during Pandemic.

title.narrative: Multisectoral response to storm victims in Maniema

description.narrative: An unrestricted cash intervention is appropriate in the affected area to cover the needs of food (for 15 days), NFIs and shelter and hygiene items, and health especially for the injured people. The local market in the area remains accessible and has availability of items. Therefore, communities will be able to acquire key food, shelter and NFI items. The cash grants will enable recipients to repair their shelters damaged by the heavy rains and strong winds, procure essential household items, buy food stock or seeds and to meet other needs of the household like health and education. This will allow them to be sheltered from the weather, reduce the likelihood of getting sick, the spread of coronavirus and provide for their immediate needs which will allow them to lead a dignified and secure life again. A lump sum will be granted to the injured to help pay for their medical care.

Each household will receive £ 170 respectively for disaster victims and £75 for host households. These amounts are within the range of the household basket values calculated by the Cash Working Group in eastern DRC. This is preferred as it ensures that households can spend the cash on what they most need. Given that the transfers are digital, it minimises the risk of theft and diversion and is a convenient and fast way to disperse funds to the disaster-affected.

"These following results will be achieved by the end of the project period: 1. Communities affected by COVID-19 in Ouanaminthe and Capotille will have increased access to responses that are relevant and appropriate. 2. Community groups capacity on leading appropriate and relevant responses increased in Ouanaminthe and Capotille. 3. The target area communities have increased skills and capacities to identify their needs and develop and implement micro-projects that address their felt needs 4. Evidence of SCLR as a model of community-led emergency response will be enhanced

title.narrative: DSK Localised emergency response transition of essential health, WaSH, and protection services

description.narrative: Critical WASH Support for 16,000 Rohingya people and host communities Improved awareness and access to GBV response and prevention services for 4000 Rohingya refugees

The project aimed to increase knowledge and awareness of Rohingya refugees on protection issues and ensure their access to GBV response and prevention services on protection issues such as human trafficking, child/early marriage, dowry, domestic violence, rape and sexual exploitation Continued operation and maintenance of WaSH infrastructure together with hygiene promotion will minimise the continued threats posed by poor hygiene and resulting health concerns which disproportionately affect women, girls and PWD. The extremely high population density in the camps combined with poor WaSH facilities will only be made worse with the start of the monsoon season which will inevitably increase the risk of contracting COVID-19, particularly for the elderly

iati-activity.iati-identifier: GB-CHC-1122330-Closing the gap on sustainable finance and enabling green recovery through capacity building in CDP’s TCFD-aligned disclosures and the GRI standards

title.narrative: Closing the gap on sustainable finance and enabling green recovery through capacity building in CDP’s TCFD-aligned disclosures and the GRI standards

description.narrative: Southeast Asia is highly vulnerable to the effects of climate change and yet has witnessed one of the highest increases in carbon dioxide emissions. In the post-COVID-19 economic recovery, it will be critical for Indonesia and Thailand to maintain their resolve on meeting their Nationally Determined Contributions (NDCs) under the Paris Agreement and continue an economic shift to low carbon model. Pertinently, as climate change is affecting people’s livelihood such as access to food, clean water and basic needs, this economic recovery also presents us with the opportunity to align environmental initiatives with social inclusion of vulnerable and historically marginalised groups such as women, LGBT community, people with disability, ethnic minorities and indigenous people. Active participation from finance and real economy sectors is needed to match policy intervention and address current ambition gaps in meeting NDC commitments and embedding long term sustainability. A resilient, low carbon economic growth will also require increased transparency and high-quality disclosure under globally recognized sustainability reporting frameworks to unlock the potential and catalyse the shift in investment practices to green and sustainable finance. To improve participation from non-policy actors, Consortium Partners will deliver a capacity building programme in partnership with strategic local stakeholders such as BAPPENAS, ICSA and Stock Exchange of Thailand (SET) for corporates and financial institutions in Indonesia and Thailand to: • address knowledge gaps in the financial implications and risk management of climate change; • establish environmental, social and governance (ESG) best practices for social inclusion and human rights; and • encourage the adoption of green and sustainable finance. Consortium partners are pioneers of climate and sustainability corporate disclosures and will build on their deep experience and strong relations with key stakeholders in Indonesia and Thailand notably: BAPPENAS, ICSA and SET to bridge current gaps that exist between local sustainable finance policies and SDG roadmaps, adoption of TCFD and corporate ESG frameworks, and accelerate the use of generated disclosure data within finance to catalyse low carbon and sustainable economic growth. Outcomes: i. Establishing an ecosystem that brings together policy, corporate ambition, and sustainable finance to enable cross-fertilization of ideas and networks that promote green recovery and meet NDC goals. ii. Financing needs identified by corporates disclosures through CDP’s TCFD-aligned platform and GRI Standards lead to demand-led growth for green and sustainable finance.

iati-activity.iati-identifier: GB-CHC-1122330-Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration

title.narrative: Promoting green recovery by championing the power of disclosure, transparency and UK-China collaboration

description.narrative:
Green finance is central to China’s attempts to green its economy and the recovery from COVID-19. The scale of capital required is huge if China is to meet its energy and climate goals, and the role of finance in combating climate change was elevated with the People’s Bank of China being included in the National Leading Group of Combating Climate Change and Energy Saving in 2018 and the establishment of the National Climate Investment and Finance Committee. Although remarkable progress has been achieved in development of green finance in China, there remain constraints among which transparency is key. Chinese policy makers and regulators are working on mandatory environmental disclosure regulations, and some local governments have already advanced their green finance agenda with more ambitious disclosure requirements; and voluntary disclosure plays an important complementary role in advancing transparency. UK-China green finance cooperation has always highlighted the role of disclosure and conducted a pilot program for FIs to disclose in line with TCFD. With deepening reform of the Chinese capital market, it will become more open to international investors, the advanced ESG investment strategy will drive for more transparent and consistent disclosure. These developments need to be supported by enhanced disclosure capacity and harmonised disclosure standards and need to be addressed urgently for lasting impact. Project approach Aim: To create an enabling environment for change supporting government, investors and FIs to shift capital at scale and thereby furthering China’s green finance agenda and NDC ambitions. The project will incentivise China’s transition to a more sustainable growth model in line with the Paris Agreement (PA) goals and the SDGs (notably targets 8.4 and 12.6). It will accelerate the work undertaken by CDP supported by the first phase of UK PACT financing, and build on CDP’s strategic global work to develop transition pathway methodologies and scoring for the financial sector, generating insights on actors who influence capital flows globally. The project will link pivotal target/beneficiary groups: (i) regulatory authorities (ii) financial institutions and/or investor (iii) investee companies. It will build capacity of these beneficiaries and network these players with international counterparts for exchange and learning.
Outcomes, respective outputs and key activities Outcome 1: Enhanced policy environment conducive to corporate environmental disclosure. 1. Knowledge products to enhance understanding of key policy makers on environmental disclosure • Comparative analysis of updated environmental disclosure policies internationally. • Demand-driven knowledge products to MEE and CSRC, as well as local governments (Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing) to strengthen environment disclosure policies/regulations/guidance. 2. Enhanced network of policy makers at national and subnational levels • Engagement and facilitated dialogue with policy makers from national and local governments (Shenzhen, Shanghai, and Beijing) to exchange research learnings and insights and at COP26.
Outcome 2: Leading FIs (banks, investors and insurers) emboldened as champions/ drivers of climate and environmental disclosure 3. Knowledge products/ tools and technical support supporting Chinese FIs to materialise their climate impact with consistent, forward looking reporting. • Build capacity of targeted FIs to respond to CDP Financial Services Sector Questionnaire and increase disclosure • Modelled GHG emissions data of CSI 300 index companies • Anthology of best practices to measure the climate risks and facilitate ESG investment
Outcome 3: Enhanced knowledge and capacity of Chinese companies and FIs to assess, disclose and address climate-related risk in line with TCFD and international standards. 4. UK-China network to enhance capacity of Chinese companies on climate disclosure and dialogue in high emitting sectors. • Chinese-UK Pilot group of companies in environmental high impact sectors to leverage learning and grow international dialogue towards quality disclosure aligned to TCFD and international standards • Dedicated technical support and feedback to pilot companies and gap analysis of disclosure. • Showcased work through Chinese and UK outlets.
5. Skills/capacity enhanced of 300 listed Chinese companies towards improving quality and quantity of TCFD-aligned disclosure • Assessment and dissemination of readiness of Chinese listed companies and FIs for TCFD-aligned disclosure • Collaborative online/onsite workshops (x 3) with GFDC in Beijing, Shanghai and Shenzhen to build skills of 300 stakeholders on disclosure and national/Shenzhen green finance policies. • Engagement with 300 listed companies from high emission impact sectors to achieve increase and quality of disclosure
6. Knowledge product: Dedicated page in TCFD Knowledge Hub housing technical documents and guidance in Chinese

title.narrative: Sierra Leone rollout of CRADLE VSA

description.narrative: This project seeks to increase access to vital signs monitoring for pregnant women in Sierra Leone through the national rollout of the CRADLE Vital Signs Alert (CVSA) device, a Blood Pressure (BP) and Heart Rate (HR) monitoring device designed for use in low-resource settings. Phase 1 of the rollout will last 18 months and be led by Welbodi Partnership. We will work in collaboration with the Ministry of Health and Sanitation (MoHS) and key partners to deliver the device and accompanying training package to health workers at all health facilities in eight of Sierra Leone’s 16 Districts. The CVSA enhances recognition of shock and pre-eclampsia/eclampsia through a novel traffic light system and alerts the user as to when intervention, often life-saving, is necessary. Following the successful pilot of the CRADLE VSA device at Princess Christian Maternity Hospital (PCMH) and 13 surrounding peripheral health units (PHU) in 2016, Welbodi Partnership is well-placed to run this project. The randomised controlled trial, which we operated in Freetown in partnership with King’s College London (KCL), demonstrated that the introduction of the CRADLE VSA device to health facilities in Sierra Leone had a positive impact on both health workers and patients: the CRADLE VSA pilot was associated with more than a 40% reduction in eclampsia, and more than a 60% reduction in maternal death in Sierra Leone. See http://cradletrial.com/ for more details of the research underpinning the device.

sector.narrative: Healthcare workers in all government facilities in 8 districts will receive training through a cascade model. The devices are provided to the facilities, alongside the training package. The Ministry of Health and Sanitation have been consulted throughout the process to ensure the project is in line with the needs of the health system and is not duplicating efforts. The training will also be extended to the midwifery and Maternal and Child Health (MCH) Aide schools so newly qualified midwives and MCH Aides will have been trained in its use. The Ministry are also encouraging extending the training to final year medical students.

Part of the project targets the communication of the results from the CRADLE VSA to the patients in an attempt to involve patients in their care, engage them in their management and increase the quality of care.

The blood pressure and heart rate monitoring device, which was designed in line with the WHO requirements for a device that is suitable for low resource settings will be provided to all government facilities across 8 of Sierra Leone's 16 districts in the Phase 1 of this rollout, contributing to medical services.

The project focuses on delivering care to women in pregnancy through the use of the CRADLE VSA to detect abnormalities in blood pressure and heart rate and recommends appropriate tailored action in the event of an abnormal result.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Global Hub Support Centre

description.narrative: Informing effective humanitarian planning and response through the provision of geospatial and data products/services to key coordination and response organisations from global through to local levels for Covid-19 measures and secondary impacts of Covid-19

Our support is via a wide range of partner organisations and we will reach affected people through these partners. Some are large scale INGO/NGOSs and UN agencies delivering direct services. Others are H2H partners including CartONG, HOT, ACAPS, Ground Truth Solutions, Translators without Borders involved in communicating with affected communities and promoting accountability.

To provide easy access to services MapAction has established a triage, prioritisation and management system, The Covid-19 Hub, within our Global Help Centre. This will enable efficient assessment of the likely impact, urgency and technical challenge of each task request. We will prioritise the requests likely to have the greatest impact on the most vulnerable populations. In particular these will be: a) Global analysis and coordination through established structures, b) Country level scale up of response, c) Support to chronic emergencies secondarily impacted by the Covid-19 storm (e.g. Current MapAction support to Camp Coordination Cluster Management in NW Syria) d) Thematic areas such as accountability. We have already started promoting the Covid-19 Service to priority countries and responding organisations.

title.narrative: START - Emergency Humanitarian Response to the COVID-19 crises in Impfondo and Epena in Likouala department

description.narrative: The project aims at ensuring the wellbeing and safety of the 4 950 direct beneficiaries, and 9 900 indirect beneficiaries affected by Covid-19 in Impfondo and Epena in Likouala department, including the flood-affected population, on prevention of COVID-19 by implementing quick-start emergency intervention in the sector of WASH.

title.narrative: DEC Indonesia Tsunami Appeal Phase 2

description.narrative:
This project is conducted in 5 villages and 2 retirement houses, building on the work of Phase 1 and the needs identified in the assessments. HelpAge/YEU will work on livelihoods, protection and health needs of older people, PWD and their families. The majority of the project activities including healthy ageing, homecare, livelihoods and protection will be delivered with and through multi-functional OPAs which enable older people and their communities to have increased agency in meeting their needs, and advocating with local government for additional support. The adopted standard OPA model focuses activities in the first 18 months, ensuring sustainability.
COVID-19 prevention activities added in 2020.

job-title.narrative: Programme Development and Funding Support Officer

mailing-address.narrative: Tavis House 1-6 Tavistock Square London WC1H 9NA

title.narrative: START - Protecting Older People headed households from COVID-19 through community-based health systems strengthening and food security initiatives

description.narrative: The project aimed to target 2500 households headed by older people in Bebedo, Nhamboca, Ndeja and Metochira Ressetlemnt Sites communities of Nhamatanda district and Mutua and Chinamcondo communities in Dondo district. The intervention was planned to strengthen linkage and coordination of community level structures with the health systems in the process of mitigating and responding to COVID-19 through: 1) Strengthening the capacity of older people structures that HelpAge has successfully developed in order to address the information gaps on COVID-19; promote referral linkages of suspected cases (HBCs will be linked with the formal health systems; and address isolation, psychosocial trauma and fear among older people. 2) To strengthen health system responses by influencing the National COVID-19 response to ensure issues of COVID-19 combined with other conditions are observed in the GoM response plan and fully addressed; 3) Direct support to older people who are self-isolating through food item distributions and provision of transport at the sufficient time to move to market to get supplies ahead of any quarantine as will be agreed with the government. 4) Provide HelpAge and partner staff with clear guidance on health awareness through training and capacity development sessions; and provision of PPE safety equipment gear for COVID-19.

title.narrative: START - Inclusive emergency response for Older People affected by tropical storm Chalane

description.narrative: The project predominantly targeted older women and men (60+), including older people with disabilities and their care givers. The project targeted 2500 HHs in Dondo and Muanza Districts of Sofala provinces. The response will focus on the following sectors: (i) Sector 1: Health- Supply covid-19 protective gear to minimize the risk of local contamination, especially with people being displaced by the effects of Chalane who are sharing shelters or houses in the resettlement sites. • Provision of preventive kits to staff, Home Based Carers, Community Monitors and Community Out Reach teams, and local partners prior to provision of training on how to use it, and dispose Provision of preventive kits (masks, gloves etc) older people, care homes, Older People Associations (OPAs); • Awareness on COVID-19 including basic information, self-care and psychosocial care through media campaigns, videos, print media, community radio; • Homecare visits by trained community volunteers, HBCs and local medical personnel for specific care and health needs. (ii) Sector 2: Food Security and Livelihoods- • Provision of relief aid – food items/ nutrition, drinking water, and other household basic supplies to needy/Internally Displaced older people/families. (iii) Sector 3: Shelter • Shelter NFI Distribution to rebuild the destroyed house and tents, to minimize the tents and public house overcrowding which is contributing for Covid-19 transmission. (iv) Sector 4: Policy and Protection Sector- • Train the project stakeholders and the community leaders on SEA, CHS, GBV, and establish complaints and feedback mechanisms for beneficiaries, to ensure that beneficiaries can address their concerns as the program is implemented.

title.narrative: START OPT 2020: Awareness and protection of older women and men against Covid-19 in the Gaza strip

description.narrative: COVID-19 emergency response for vulnerable older women and men in Gaza. Through its international and national partners, HelpAge International UK aimed to protect older men and women through hygiene kits, PPE, and awareness raising.

title.narrative: START: Provision of PPE, hygiene items, awareness raising, cash, food security in response to COVID-19 in Colombia

description.narrative: Rapid humanitarian response to impacts of the COVID-19 crisis on Older Persons, People with Disabilities, and Venezuelan Caminantes, returnees and homeless in La Guajira, North Santander and Santander, Colombia

title.narrative: START Syria 2020: Strengthening COVID-19 emergency response for vulnerable older women and men in Idlib in NW Syria

description.narrative: Strengthening COVID-19 emergency response for vulnerable older women and men in Idlib in NW Syria. Through its international and national partners, HelpAge International UK aimed to reach one of the most vulnerable groups in the community who are usually a hidden segment in any society, especially in humanitarian contexts. Our main target group was be older men and women including those with disabilities in Idlib governorate, in urban, camps and Informal Tented Settlements (ITS) settings.

title.narrative: START - Inclusive COVID-19 response to Older persons, people with disability and vulnerable persons in North Uganda, West Nile and Karamoja Sub Regions

description.narrative: The project focused on increasing resilience of older persons and school going children under their care to respond to the impact of COVID-19 pandemic and government restrictions, through strengthening protection and increasing access to WASH facilities at community level. The project conducted a rapid capacity building campaign through sensitization and access to age appropriate and ease to use IEC materials to communities focussing on older persons on appropriate COVID-19 pandemic prevention, mitigation and response mechanisms as per the Ministry of Health guidelines and in line with the national COVID-19 response policy 2020. It procured and distributed PPE to beneficiaries working closely with the district local governments, other institution where communities gather like churches, schools and mosques. We distributed temperature guns, hand sanitizers, liquid soap and install hand washing facilities at 125 facilities across the sub region.

title.narrative: Healthier info-ecosystems for healthier people

description.narrative:
Immediate objective 1: Information Eco-system assessment to identify relevant information/communication channels used by migrant communities in Bangkok to access and share information related to COVID-19 to understand the specific complexities migrants face when accessing information and services related to COVID-19.
Immediate objective 2: Connecting data-collection, analysis and production-activities across the region to enable demand-driven content in locally relevant languages and as such bridge the trust-gap that allows reliable information to gain more traction.

The focus of the Internews H2H-intervention is to enable more reality- and demand-driven communication across the region in all issues emerging from and related to the COVID-19-response. Based on expertise gained during previous health-emergencies and building on the Misinformation Management methodologies, Internews aims to increase trust in and therefore traction of reliable and locally relevant information, by connecting data-collection and monitoring activities (including social media monitoring, rumour tracking and community engagement activities by Internews and others), with the latest vetted information coming from health experts and agencies and using its media and social-media expertise to provide information packages that combine both in a format that enables local media to create content that is best fit for their outlet, channel and audience, in the language they like and understand.

Ethiopia Emergency Covid-19 Response Fund

description.narrative: The Freedom Fund has established a Covid-19 Emergency Response Fund (ERF) to offer immediate humanitarian assistance through small-scale funding to some 100 frontline partners working with vulnerable communities in India, Nepal, Myanmar, Ethiopia, Thailand and Brazil (part of its established hotspot programme).

The project specifically provides: 1. Emergency relief to affected groups, including food, shelter, sanitation needs, protective equipment for shelter staff, transportation, healthcare-related costs. 2. Surge capacity for NGO advocacy, to monitor needs of vulnerable groups, ensure government response is appropriate and reaching those who need assistance. 3. Microgrants to savings & loans groups, self-help groups, and other existing community structures to provide credit and help absorb financial shocks.

title.narrative: H2H COVID-19 Response

description.narrative: In this project, the target audience has global reach to support all actors working on the COVID response. There will be a special focus on Sudan and Zimbabwe for the National Coordinator activity, and existing national CCE platforms, working closely with CDAC member agencies on this service provision component. Strong links with be created in each country with MoH’s, WHO and RCCEs to ensure consistency in messaging. As COVID-19 restrictions will likely apply to the project timeline, it is unlikely that project teams will be working directly with the affected population but will be linking with its operational members and response partners as part of technical services support.

Strengthen CCEA through improved coordination and the rapid collation, generation and dissemination of health messaging related to COVID-19, relevant to humanitarian settings, grounded on a strong evidence base. Activities will include: • Develop a concise CDAC Lessons Paper laying out the key CCEA lessons from previous pandemics (and previous infectious disease outbreaks), including drawing from countries that have already reached the peak in the current COVID-19 response; and rapidly disseminate especially in countries that are only beginning to experience COVID-19 • Deploy Senior National CCE coordinators to Sudan and Zimbabwe, defining the role and working working with CDAC UN, Red Cross, NGO and specialized members in-country • Provide CCEA technical support to existing CCEA National Platforms as they address COVID-19 in the context of ongoing disaster responses • Mobilise 25 CCEA coordinators post Nairobi CCEA Coordinator training in Jan 2020 and agree on plan for leveraging their expertise in multiple country contexts as part of the ongoing response; and ensuring capacity on CCEA is strengthened where possible given the COVID restrictions, using adapted CDAC training materials.

This project focuses on strengthening CCEA through improved coordination and the rapid collation, generation and dissemination of health messaging related to COVID-19, relevant to humanitarian settings, grounded on a strong evidence base.
Learning from both current and emerging disasters (such as that from Cyclone Harold in the Pacific) and as many disaster-prone countries are just beginning this crisis, this project, will: set out concise CCEA-specific lessons from previous responses; deploy two national staff to coordinate CCEA platforms in Sudan and Zimbabwe; and provide CCEA technical support remotely to existing national CCEA platforms.

title.narrative: Project to prevent the spread of the Covid-19 pandemic in southern Benin

description.narrative: This project is designed to limit the spread of Covid -19 in Benin. To achieve this objective, the project is structured around 3 main activities and oriented according to the specific needs of the geographic areas and the expertise of the partners: 1.Better understanding to act better: this objective addresses the actions individuals, families and communities must take to control the threat to Covid -19. It is community engagement based on fair access to information and the right to know about health risks and the duty to protect yourself and others. 2. Strengthen prevention and response measures at community level: this objective aims to support communities in terms of materials and equipment (eg handwashing devices, masks, gloves, etc.) in order to better apply prevention and response measures. 3.Support sanitary devices: this objective aims to support the government and community health centers in the diagnosis of cases (detection kit, provision of protective equipment for nursing staff) and compliance with care guidelines and monitoring of contacts of affected people.

title.narrative: Responding to the increased risk of gender violence in El Salvador due to COVID

description.narrative: This action proposes an intervention focused on responding to the main needs of women at risk and victims of gender violence. The three pillars of action will be: 1) Basic and protection needs: delivery of unconditional cash transfer for female victims that allows them access to essential items as well as economic means for their self -protection. 2) Provide access to the necessary information related to the prevention of gender -based violence and the means of referral to response and protection services. 3) Psychosocial support to people at risk and victims of gender violence: capacities will be strengthened for psychologists to give psychosocial and crisis support to women and adolescents.

title.narrative: Response to urgent humanitarian needs of food crisis & COVID 19 in Somalia

description.narrative: In response to food insecurity resulting from COVID 19 impact on livelihoods crises coupled by GATI cyclone, the project will support people affected by Cyclone, IDP and host community (HC) women, men, boys and girls in Bari region by meeting basic needs, maintaining dignity, and saving lives through Unconditional Cash Transfers(UCT)and Cash -for -Work (CFW) assistance. Unconditional cash transfer will be provided to 800 HHs (4800 people) in GATI hit communities who will receive immediate food needs. Further more 750HH (4500 people) affected by COVID 19 economically will be supported to receive two rounds of unconditional cash transfer in Somaliland. Each benefiting household will electronically (via mobilephones) receive CT valued at USD85 per round in Puntland and Somaliland target regions. The project will rehabilitate four communal structures where 200HHs(1200 people) will be involved in cash for work activity for a period of two months and earn income.

title.narrative: Covid-19 Prevention in Host Communities in Mafraq impacted by the Syrian crisis

description.narrative: This project targets Syrian refugee and vulnerable Jordanian households in 2 municipalities in Mafraq Governorate (Um Aljmal Municipality and Za'atari Municipality – these can be adjusted to other Oxfam operational areas nearby in coordination with WASH Working Group). The project is based on Oxfam's Rapid Needs Assessment (May 2020) in these two municipalities, which indicated a need for hygiene and cleaning items. The project aims to distribute 3,000 hygiene kits (1 months' supply), targeted towards the most vulnerable households, which will be selected based on vulnerability criteria. This is expected to reach 15,000 people. The contents of the hygiene kit are targeted at infants, children, women and adolescent girls. The kits will include IEC materials with messages on Covid -19, hygiene, contact details for GBV services, mental health tips, and feedback and complaints contact details. The IEC materials available will include a video version in sign language with voice and subtitles to increase accessibility of information. Hygiene kits will be distributed house -to -house to prevent the protection risks associated with distributions and prevent heavy and bulky kits needing to be transported by beneficiaries. A female member of Oxfam staff will be present during each household visit. The project compliments Oxfam's funded Covid -19 response in these two municipalities which targets the population with Risk Communication and Community Engagement (RCCE) for Covid -19. Oxfam has an existing relationship with 2 local CBOs, the relevant Municipalities and communities in the two project locations, easing access and selection of beneficiaries. Identification of beneficiaries and Post Distribution Monitoring will purposely seek out the opinions of women, refugees and people with disabilities across all adult ages. Protection actors in the area will be able to refer households to Oxfam to receive a Hygiene Kit. Due to the risks of the impact of Covid -19 on access, all monitor

title.narrative: COVID-19 Cash assistance to vulnerable Syrians and Jordanians

description.narrative: Like in many parts of the world where strict lock down measures were imposed, the impacts of lock down and restrictions on commercial activity and the resulting impact on employment have been significant,In Jordan, the most vulnerable population – low income Jordanians and refugees (of multiple nationalities) have been impacted even further as many of them found themselves out of work and outside of official safety nets such as the National Aid Fund (NAF) and Social Security Corporation (SSC). Oxfam is using the appeal fund to pilot unconditional cash transfer scheme starting with a small amount to assess accuracy in targeting particularly; operational efficiency in using e -wallets; and impact of cash transfers on intra -household gender roles and relations.

title.narrative: Covid-19 response, Social Safety Nets for Vulnerable Households, Kenya

description.narrative: 20,000 most vulnerable households to be targeted for cash transfers mostly comprising women, the elderly, the chronically ill, persons with disabilities and child -headed households,. Oxfam will work with the following partners: Kenya Red Cross Society, Concern, ACTED, Wangu Kanja Foundation, Centre for Rights Education and Awareness (CREAW) and Impact Initiatives to provide monthly cash transfers for three months starting in May 2020 valued at KES 7,668 (EUR 68) per household per month, which is 50% of the Minimum Expenditure Basket (MEB ). The action will complement the cash transfer programme with GBV prevention interventions to mitigate any Gender Based Violence related risks such as intimate partner violence that may arise as a result of disbursing cash to women. The project will deliver messaging to targeted communities encouraging the redistribution of care work between men and women in households and communities. The Gender Based Violence mitigation strategies will help protect women and girls at risk of sexual and other physical violence that prevails during lockdown.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response -Lebanon -WASH, Protection and Food Security

description.narrative: Outcome 1: Improved WASH standards in ISs in North Bekaa, in line with COVID -19 prevention, isolation and quarantine guidelines. The proposed WASH intervention will focus on emergency WASH activities (life -saving WASH services). The WASH activities will be implemented through a safe programming approach with the involvement of affected communities. This will be done in close coordination with the two municipalities. Accordingly, WASH activities will reach 4,746 Syrian refugees (2,310 women; 2,436 men) in 93 ISs in Saaide and Bouday. The nature of the WASH intervention will depend on the isolation guidance levels. Outcome 2: Improved access by refugees, especially women and girls, to reliable and comprehensive information on COVID -19 prevention Oxfam's initial response to COVID -19 was to engage communities. Ensuring trusted and two -way communication channels is a top priority in the current situation and moving forward, so that communities can receive and share information and engage in developing solutions to challenges being raised. Based on the initial discussions, questions raised were prioritized and addressed in the form of Frequently Asked Questions (FAQs), thereby contextualizing the COVID -19 information on the most ‘need -to -know' basis, in addition to besides the WASH and Health sectors' agreed messaging. Given the protracted nature of the humanitarian response in Lebanon; the response had mostly transitioned to a cash -based response in line with Grand Bargain commitment to "increase the use and coordination of cash -based programming." However, given the mobility challenges that the COVID -19 crisis brings on refugee communities to access cash, coupled with the ongoing challenges of the banking sector in Lebanon due to the economic and financial situation; as part of the COVID -19 response strategy, LCRP partners are asked to prepare for likely food distribution for Levels 2, 3 and 4. Also, interactive programs will be prepared and broadcast on community radio stations about prevention measures and behavioural changes in the face of the disease. - Digital communication will make it possible to reach the different components of the population in the areas of intervention of Oxfam projects through social networks - Facebook pages, WhatsApp groups and others. To do this, digital resources and content will be developed around key messages. - Hygiene kits such as hand washing, soap, gloves and personal protective masks will be distributed to health facilities. title.narrative: Creating Space to Take Action on Violence Against Women and Girls- ( COVID-19 )

description.narrative: The proposed five year program will reduce violence against women and girls, and the prevalence of early, forced and child marriage. The program will achieve this ultimate outcome through a holistic, multi -pronged and multi -generation approach to ending violence against women and girls. First, it will create an enabling environment to prevent violence against women and girls by engaging key, influential religious, community, private sector and political leaders as well as young men and women in advancing women's leadership, women's rights and the elimination of violence against women and girls. These community leaders and youth will act as champions of change, decreasing the social acceptability of violence and modeling positive behaviors within the social spheres in which they are most influential. Training will be undertaken for them to better understand the rights of women and girls, the different forms of violence, as well as the role they each must play in ending violence. Practical tools will be developed to ensure these actors are supported in their on -going efforts to model positive behaviors. The program will include annual round tables and exchange visits to strategise long -term solutions and build momentum around prevention. In addition, the program will support key religious, community, private sector and political leaders to strengthen or change standards, legislation, and regulations. A comprehensive, context -specific baseline analysis will be undertaken in each program location.

title.narrative: Empower Youth for Work in Pakistan ( COVID-19 )

description.narrative: The project's ambition is that young people in Pakistan are empowered and have improved skills and jobs. This is a multi -country project that includes Bangladesh, Ethiopia and Indonesia in addition to Pakistan. This program focuses specifically on Small Medium Enterprise (SME) development; improved jobs; skills development for youth; climate change, and Life Skills. This project works with holistic approach working around three building blocks 1. Agency, capacity and skills 2. Economic opportunities 3. Policy and norms Youth will be co -creators and co -implementers. Through civil society partners, and close links with the private sector and government institute, we ensure that improved skills training is adopted within local structures and innovative social enterprises; unemployment is tackled through improved private sector practice, increased market access and new enterprise development; an enabling social environment is created through grassroots and mass media action. Climate change, resilience, gender and youth empowerment are mainstreamed. 70% of beneficiaries will be rural young women. Overall it aspires to economically empower the rural youth especially young girls by imparting the required soft and market led skills to engage in economic learning cycle. But in order to fulfil this aspiration we need to build the confidence of girls by imparting Life Skills Based Education which in turn will pave the path for economic empowerment. Additionally none of this is possible until and unless policy and practice level change is in place in both districts Jamshoro (Sindh) and Layyah (Punjab). So mobilisation and lobbying with government and private sector companies (inclusive of Micro Enterprises (MEs), Small Medium Enterprise (SME) and Multi -National Corporations (MNCs) to make pro youth and specifically pro girls working environment shall also be carried out.

This includes adopting climate -smart agricultural techniques, diversifying livelihoods, and applying an appropriately designed risk transfer mechanism which will be developed in partnership with non -traditional actors including micro -insurance. The project specifically targets women, young people, and people with disabilities who are particularly vulnerable to the impacts of disasters and climate change in Badin.

title.narrative: Humanitarian Response to the COVID-19 pandemic

description.narrative: The expanding global outbreak of the Coronavirus remains uncontrolled with total confirmed cases 533,015 (Globally) and total deaths 24,095 as of 27 -3 -2020 in 199 Countries and Territories. The confirmed case fatality ratio is still being assessed. As of 27th April, there have been more than 12,723 confirmed cases of COVID -19 in Pakistan, with 281 deaths reported. The estimated total population of Pakistan is around 220.89 million making it the fifth most populous country in the world with approximately two -thirds of the population residing in rural areas with no access to hospitals equipped to deal with coronavirus patients, or sometimes to any medical facilities at all. Owing to poor health seeking behaviours a weak health system in Pakistan, it is feared that the identified cases may be just the tip of the iceberg. Considering the impact of COVID -19 pandemic disaster impact, it is proposed that key measures be undertaken rapidly to prevent and contain the further spread of the infection in Pakistan. As duty of care for staff, partners, and vulnerable communities, large gatherings will be avoided through above mentioned outsourced channels where possible. A key consideration would be to adopt strategies which prevent panic and paranoia amongst the people and ensure safety of the targeted population. The approaches for this is outlined below: - Mass awareness and communications campaign for Infection prevention and control - Provision of WASH Service and Supplies and personal protective equipment - Addressing the economic crisis through relief support - Promoting livelihood diversification and entrepreneurship - Supporting protection and shelter mechanisms for women, girls and marginalized groups

description.narrative: This 45 days project implementation period will be appropriate for the immediate needs while the medium to long term needs arising from the floods damage are being planned for and additional resources mobilised under the coordination of the government. This response will also provide a complimentary response to the food assistance currently under way to meet the immediate gaps. Moreover, as Rwanda continues the fight of COVID -19, the project will be instrumental to mitigate the spread of COVID -19 for the affected population as it will allow targeted households to go to their homes, and leave temporary shelter where conditions are not conducive to required hygiene and social distancing for COVID -19 prevention. Based on the identified needs and the proposed funding amount, this project prioritizes the basic lifesaving responses: 1. Shelter: Distribution of basic construction materials such as iron sheets and galvanized wires. 2. Non -food Items (NFIs): Distribution of critical and strategic NFIs such as Blankets, Mats, Jerricans, Bathing soap, Washing soap, Buckets, Pads, Tooth brushes, Tooth Pastes, Saucepans, Plates, Cups and Folks. 3.WASH: The will intervention will ensure that the floods victims have access to the basic m basic hygiene and sanitation items. The project will also contibute to the beneficiaries' hygiene behaviour change towards disaster and COVID -19, contributing to the ongoing efforts on DRR and COVID -19 awareness.This includes early floods warnign messaging and COVID -19 wareness among the affected population and targeted Districts. This project component will work with pre -existing disaster risk reduction structures in the communities to intensify DRR and COVID -19 awareness.

title.narrative: COVID-19 Response in Hajjah

description.narrative: - Wells rehabilitation in Hajjah. Oxfam will target 7 open dug wells in Mabian district. This intervention will benefit from it 717 HHs. Quick assessment confirmed that people in this area collect water from the 7 dug wells for drinking water which considered as contaminated water. In addition, collecting water is a tough job for women and girls as they have to walk more than 2 km to the water source. The intervention need will include excavation and filling around of well Paving stone; Supply and build solid concrete block to increase the wall of dug well installed steel/fibber cover; construction of basin for animals drinking; cleaning and chlorination from contamination. Rehabilitate of these sources will reduce the risk of infection and the spread of the COVID -19 as well as other water borne diseases related to water pollution, acute watery diarrhea and cholera.
